title-group.article-title: SARS‐CoV‐2 Virulence: Interplay of Floating Virus‐Laden Particles, Climate, and Humans

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2020 WILEY‐VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim

license.license-p: This article is being made freely available through PubMed Central as part of the COVID-19 public health emergency response. It can be used for unrestricted research re-use and analysis in any form or by any means with acknowledgement of the original source, for the duration of the public health emergency.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: With the emergence of COVID‐19, it is important to address the possible scenarios of SARS‐CoV‐2 virulence. Although several researchers have addressed the possible mechanisms of enveloped virus transfection, for example, influenza, here, the relationship between exhaled virus laden‐particles, the climate, and transfection probability is discussed by interpreting the findings of prior studies. Importantly, the higher probability of viral transfection in cold and dry public spaces such as near cold shelves of groceries is illustrated. Thus, additional protective measures in such spaces are recommended.

The virulence of enveloped viruses such as SARS‐CoV‐2 and influenza has been studied from different perspectives, although the interplay of climate and virus‐laden particles has not been assessed thus far. In this essay, evidence to show how the manmade local climate or natural and seasonal climate might affect the virulence of exhaled virus‐laden aerosols is presented.

caption.p: The effect of climate on virulence of enveloped viruses. In cold climate, enveloped viruses are viable for several hours, while the low humidity of cold climate aids exhaled virus‐laden aerosols turn to tiny solid residues that can remain suspended in air for several hours and might travel within air flow. In mild and humid climate, most of the virus‐laden aerosols precipitate faster since the evaporation is slower. Also, a relatively shorter viability compared to cold climate is expected in mild temperature. Hot and dry climate, although aids faster formation of solid residues, but high temperature destabilizes the enveloped viruses and shortens their viable period.

sec.title: Conflict of Interest
sec.p: The authors declare no conflict of interest.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The author would like to acknowledge Prof. Ali Khademhosseini for his support and SNF Postdoctoral Fellowship (P2EZP2_187980).

bio.p: Vahid Hosseini received his Doctorate in Pharmacy from the Tehran University of Medical Science, Iran; Master of Materials and Nanotechnology from the Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden; and D.Sc. in the field of Health Science and Technology from the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland (ETH). He currently serves as a Swiss National Foundation (SNF) Postdoctoral Fellow in the laboratory of Prof. Khademhosseini, Department of Bioengineering, University California at Los Angeles, USA.
